reviews.review:
A sequel to Half Life 2. Pretty short, so get it on a sale. Recommended if you want the content for Garry's Mod or if you're a big fan of the game and want to play the whole franchise.

Recommended, although too short.
8/10

Episode one is less of an add-on or expansion as it is a direct continuation of the base game's story, picking up seconds after it ended. This means two things. 

The positive is that it expands on the top class gameplay and world of Half-Life 2 while introducing us to some new enemy types and new areas. The negative is that paying ‚Ç¨7 to experience the next 4 hours of the story feels a little cheap, like it should have been included in the base game.

For better or worse, Episode one is a necessary but very short component to Half-Life 2 and a welcome addition to those who crave more of it. 8/10

The next great installment of our late hero Dr. Freemen.

All in all, it's a nice short advancement where Half-Life 2 left off. Keyword being SHORT. You could probably play through this at a normal pace and complete it in about 2.5 hours. Nonetheless, still worth a play if you yearn for more after Half-Life 2.
‰∏çÂ•ΩÁé©

Quarter-Life 2

Basically a miniature half life 2. Good fun if you liked HL2.

I can't complain about Episode 1 because it is more Half-Life but it is definitely weaker than the full game. Feeling more like a tacked on epilogue, Episode 1 feels like it acts merely to connect the end of the core game to the next major part of the story. What does stand out about this game is the character interaction. The improvement of NPC intelligence means that your companion throughout the entire episode is actually effective in gameplay, not to mention keeping you company in the darker, lonelier parts of the episode. This is what I feel this game was to be, however, a smaller scope character driven adventure. For this I can applauded the game because there are some parts of the story that truly make you care as if your companion were real flesh and blood.

[b]Full review below if you want to check it out:[/b]

Really good game, a lot of fun to play, i recomend this game to anyone, its an old classic

A lot of people say the original is always better then the sqeual. I have to disagree. This is a game who does it right when they say "Alright god dammit we're gonna make a second chapter of this game and where gonna do it right!". There is so much to say about this game, the massive cult following it's gain to it's various RP servers it's spun off in GMOD. It's massive amount of lore to it's amazing combat system. It's nothing but amazing! There is so much to learn, so much to enjoy, so much to love! I know I sound like I'm kissing ‚ô•‚ô•‚ô• when I say this but this game makes me love valve more than anything. Either being the same badass scientist that crawled his way out of that hell hole known as Black Mesa smashing Crowbars into the ugly guls of Alien Monsters now into the Gasmask of Metro Police Officers that opress a civilian populace under a Universal Union Banner in the name of "Civil Status". Or riding around in a scrapped sports car with a rather attractive but at the same time a TRUE strong and independant female character Alyx. You feel like a badass actually doing something for a resistance, no, a revolution for mankind being enslaved by a Alien Empire. This game is perfect. This game is art.

A great sequel, short but sweet also the gfx are improved and there are new enemies :D 9/10

This game is of course a follow-up on the Half-Life 2 adventures, and what exactly happened after the tower ending in which there was no conclusion to in the main installment. This exact episode will take you through the story about the escape from the great area (and tower) before it explodes completely, which would mean the death of Freeman, Alyx, and pretty much everyone in a great scale area, so it is about escaping ASAP. Afterwards it will take you through the pressing task of saving as many remaining citizens as possible from City 17 before the - again - explosion. Essentially, it is all about escaping City 17. 

A must if you¬¥re a fan of the series. This episode in particular is only really challenging in the end when it starts firing all sorts of enemies at your face, but is fairly casual-friendly up until the ending chapters - at least on normal and "expert". Well, not so much on expert. ;)

Have fun!

Half-Life 2: Episode One ist definitiv ein guter Teil dieses Universums, kann aber das schwindelerregende Niveau des Hauptspiels nicht erreichen. 
Das gr√∂√üte Problem f√ºr mich bei dieser Erweiterung ist wie begrenzt, eng und √ºber-linear sich alles anf√ºhlt. Das bahnbrechende Leveldesign mit neuen Szenarien und Herausforderungen aus dem Hauptspiel sind mehr oder minder verschwunden und Episode One wird leider zu einem zu ballerlastigen Kurztrip in das Universum von Gordon Freeman. 

Auch storytechnisch gibt es recht wenig neues zu entdecken. Positiv zu vermerken in diesem Bereich bleibt die wachsende Beziehung zu Alex, die in diesem Abenteuer eine zentrale Rolle spielt. Leider wird die doch recht kurze Spielzeit auch zu h√§ufig durch Konversationen unterbrochen - gerade der erste Teil ist pausenloses Stop-and-Go, sodass man st√§ndig das Bed√ºrfnis hat, endlich von der Leine gelassen zu werden. 

Bei alle dem bleibt Episode One immer noch ein Half-Life Titel und so sehr man auch sp√ºrt, dass es nicht ganz die Erwartung erf√ºllt, so viel Spa√ü hat man dennoch w√§hrend des gesamten Spieldurchlaufs. Das Ende macht einen auch wirklich gespannt, was einen wohl in Episode Two erwartet.
its actually episode 2 of half life 2 but if half life 2 was really chapter 2 then its chapter three which means its half life three

Excellent, dans la lign√©e de HL2.
Le seul b√©mol c'est qu'il est vraiment trop court... en 3h c'est boucl√© ^^ Mais bon, √ßa vaut le coup :)

An interesting add-on to the Half Life 2 franchise.

Gordon Freeman and Alex are saved from the ending of HL2 (not going to reveal too much there) and must excape from the giant citidel. They encounter tons of Combine along the way and must solve a lot of devious problems and puzzles to escape. They bond along the way as well.

HLE1 pushes the action of HL2 but does not do a whole bunch with the story. You get a wider perspective of the world as Gordon and Alex rush out of the citidel but still not much backstory to either of them, any of the other characters or the Combine. 

The action is great, everything else is great, it's just that this chapter is not the top of the top in terms of what you usually get with a Half Life game.

Still, you must play through it if you want the whole story.

8/10

I played Episode One for the first time last month for like an hour and forgot about it till I completed it in a single playthrough yesterday. All I can say is, and I don't want to get slaughtered for this, I was pretty underwhelmed. Maybe it's the short campaign with very little significance to the storyline. Yeah, well you got some data you weren't supposed to see and now you need to hoof till the train station battling hoards of enemies. That's the plot in one sentence. Not much happened here, but the only reason I am underwhelmed is because I expected much more reading other reviews. It was a decent additional content to the main game, and Episode Two is supposed to be way better, so looking forward to it.

Gameplay wise, if you liked Half-Life 2, you won't find any difference here. Graphics are marginally better with HDR, I guess. We've come too far to even notice the difference anyway. But we don't play Half-Life games for the graphics, do we?

Overall, I'd recommend it for maintaining the continuity and for storyline reasons.

More of the same Half-Life 2 goodness. And that ain't a bad thing!

10/10

Chester Alan Arthur (October 5, 1829 ‚Äì November 18, 1886) was an American attorney and politician who served as the 21st President of the United States (1881‚Äì85); he succeeded James A. Garfield upon the latter's assassination. At the outset, Arthur struggled to overcome a slightly negative reputation, which stemmed from his early career in politics as part of New York's Republican political machine. He succeeded by embracing the cause of civil service reform. His advocacy for, and subsequent enforcement of, the Pendleton Civil Service Reform Act was the centerpiece of his administration.

Arthur was born in Fairfield, Vermont, grew up in upstate New York, and practiced law in New York City. He served as quartermaster general in the New York Militia during the American Civil War. Following the war, he devoted more time to Republican politics and quickly rose in the political machine run by New York Senator Roscoe Conkling. Appointed by President Ulysses S. Grant to the lucrative and politically powerful post of Collector of the Port of New York in 1871, Arthur was an important supporter of Conkling and the Stalwart faction of the Republican Party. In 1878, the new president, Rutherford B. Hayes, fired Arthur as part of a plan to reform the federal patronage system in New York. When Garfield won the Republican nomination for president in 1880, Arthur, an eastern Stalwart, was nominated for vice president to balance the ticket.

After just half a year as vice president, Arthur found himself in the executive mansion due to the assassination of his predecessor. To the surprise of reformers, Arthur took up the cause of reform, though it had once led to his expulsion from office. He signed the Pendleton Act into law and strongly enforced its provisions. He gained praise for his veto of a Rivers and Harbors Act that would have appropriated federal funds in a manner he thought excessive. He presided over the rebirth of the United States Navy, but was criticized for failing to alleviate the federal budget surplus, which had been accumulating since the end of the Civil War.

Suffering from poor health, Arthur made only a limited effort to secure the Republican Party's nomination in 1884; he retired at the close of his term. Journalist Alexander McClure later wrote, "No man ever entered the Presidency so profoundly and widely distrusted as Chester Alan Arthur, and no one ever retired ... more generally respected, alike by political friend and foe."[3] Although his failing health and political temperament combined to make his administration less active than a modern presidency, he earned praise among contemporaries for his solid performance in office. The New York World summed up Arthur's presidency at his death in 1886: "No duty was neglected in his administration, and no adventurous project alarmed the nation."[4] Mark Twain wrote of him, "[I]t would be hard indeed to better President Arthur's administration."[5] Over the 20th and 21st centuries, however, Arthur's reputation mostly faded among the public.

More challenging than Half-Life 2....but too damn short. Worth buying only when is on sale

This episode's story isn't that charming like main story from Half Life 2, but it replaces with puzzle that is nailing my feeling all the time. Even though Half Life 2 : episode one seems not to popular, I would say it is one of the good games from Valve if you're a big fan of half life. Gameplay is pretty smooth, and the most important thing is puzzles aren't that annoying to solve; you can figure it out in 5-10 minutes at least because everything that will make you to pass the mission is in the same scene. I strongly recommend this game for single player - it is fun and worthy of your money :)
